docs.title: Tabular
docs.text: Provide [go-cobra]-style tab-completions for your Crystal CLI. While it is opinionated in it's adherence to the [go-cobra] convention, it is unopionionated in how you get there.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Add the dependency to your shard.yml:
dependencies:
 tabular:
   github: leshaunj/tabular
  1. Run shards install

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Ensure Tabular is imported into your project.

require "tabular"

docs.title: Tokens
docs.text:
A Tabular::Token represents any possible suggestion the end-user will receive, given their current argument. Tabular comes with three built-in Tabular::Token styles:

require "tabular"

my_tokens = Tabular.tokens(
  Tabular.option("--opt", ["-o"], "A simple boolean flag"),

  Tabular.option("--arg-opt", ["-a"],
                 "A flag that expects any argument",
                 Tabular.argument(description: "Will suggest available files")),

  Tabular.option("--spec-arg", ["-s"],
                 description: "A flag that expects a choice of arguments",
                 Tabular.argument("choice1"),
                 Tabular.argument("choice2"),
                 Tabular.argument("choice3")),

  Tabular.option("--file-opt", ["-f"],
                 "A flag that expects a certain file type",
                 Tabular.argument("yaml", ["yml"], directives: :filter_ext)),

  Tabular.option("--dir-opt", ["-d"],
                 "A flag that expects any directory",
                 Tabular.argument(directives: :filter_dir)),

  Tabular.option("--dir-opt", ["-D"],
                 "A flag that expects any directory within a specific directory",
                 Tabular.argument("path/to/dir", directives: :filter_dir)),

  Tabular.command("action1", ["act1"], "A subcommand"),
  Tabular.command("action2", ["act2"], "Another subcommand"),
)

Tip

You can also create you own bespoke tokens with the base Tabular.Token class.

docs.title: Reply
docs.text:
Once you have your Tabular::Tokens, invoke Tabular.reply when the __complete subcommand is called on your CLI. It will determine the suggestions and print them to STDOUT:

require "tabular"

if ARGV[0]? == "__complete"
  ARGV.shift

  # Read arguments from `ARGV` or supply your own
  Tabular.reply my_tokens # , ["-a", "--bee", "cee", "dee"]
end

If you provide a block to Tabular.reply, said block is called when a Tabular.command is matched, handing control back to your CLI:

require "tabular"

if ARGV[0]? == "__complete"
  ARGV.shift

  Tabular.reply my_tokens do |current|
    case current.name
    when "subcmd1" then Subcommand1.new.complete ARGV
    when "subcmd2" then Subcommand2.new.complete ARGV
    end
  end
end

Any unhandled Tabular.command tokens will fallback to default completion behaviour for the given shell.

Warning

When providing both a block and your own argument list, ensure your argument list is passed as a variable. Tabular.reply will modify this variable as needed so you can forward it to nested commands.

docs.title: Installer
docs.text:
Call Tabular.install! when the completion (or what you choose) subcommand is called on your CLI:

require "tabular"

if ARGV[0]? == "completion"
  ARGV.shift

  begin
    # Read arguments from `ARGV` or supply your own
    Tabular.install! # ["bash"]
  rescue e : Tabular::Error
    puts e
    exit 1
  end
end

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
Note

See Contributing documentation

docs.title: .argument(*, choices = [] of String, description = "", directives : Directable | Nil = nil)
docs.text:
Create a Tabular::Token as a Tabular::Kind::Argument.

  • description: See Tabular::Token#description.
  • directives: See Tabular::Token#directives.

docs.title: .completion_cmd : String
docs.text:
Return the name of the CLI argument that will prompt completions.

View source

docs.title: .completion_cmd=(value : String)
docs.text:
Set the name of the CLI argument that will prompt completions.

View source

docs.title: .delimiters : String
docs.text:
A global string of characters that may delimit a Tabular::Token of Tabular::Kind::Option.

View source

docs.title: .delimiters=(value : String)
docs.text:
Specify the global string of characters that may delimit a Tabular::Token of Tabular::Kind::Option.

# Allows for something like `--option=`
Tabular.delimiters = "="
# Allows for something like `-option:`
Tabular.delimiters = ":"
# Allows for all of the above
Tabular.delimiters = ":="
View source

docs.title: .find(tokens : Tokens, arg : String)
docs.text:
Return the first Tabular::Token in tokens that starts with args.

View source

docs.title: .install!(args = ARGV, *, program : String = PROGRAM_NAME, command = Tabular.completion_cmd)
docs.text:
Sends a completion script for shell specified in args.

  • args: A list of user-specified arguments for the installer.
  • <shell>: The shell to install the completions for (supports: bash, fish, zsh).
  • --development <path>: An alternate path to alias the CLI name to.
  • program: The name of the CLI program. Best not to set this one.
  • command: The subcommand the completion script will call to get completions.
View source

docs.title: .option(name : String, aliases = [] of String, description = "", *argument, directives : Directable | Nil = nil, delimiters = Tabular.delimiters)
docs.text:
Create a Tabular::Token as a Tabular::Kind::Option.

  • name: See Tabular::Token#name.
  • aliases: See Tabular::Token#aliases.
  • description: See Tabular::Token#description.
  • argument: See Tabular::Token#arguments.
  • directives: See Tabular::Token#directives.
  • delimiters: Ad hoc delimiters that will override Tabular.delimiters.
View source

docs.title: .reply(tokens : Tokens, args = ARGV) : Bool
docs.text:
Verify the arguments in args[0,-1] and send suggestions to STDOUT for any Tabular::Token in tokens that starts with args[-1].

View source

docs.title: .reply(tokens : Tokens, args = ARGV, &forward : Token -> Bool) : Bool
docs.text:
Verify the arguments in args[0,-1] and send suggestions to STDOUT for any Tabular::Token in tokens that starts with args[-1].

When a Tabular::Kind::Command type is matched, hand control back to the CLI via the specifed &forward.

View source

docs.title: .tokens(from : Enumerable(*T), &block : *T -> Token | Nil) : Tokens
docs.text:
Create a Tabular::Tokens collection by transforming the elements of from with the provided &block.

View source

docs.title: .tokens(*tokens : Token) : Tokens
docs.text:
Create a Tabular::Tokens collection.

docs.title: module Tabular::Completers
docs.text: A collection of convenience functions to handle completion situations.

docs.title: .install(args = ARGV)
docs.text:
A convenience completer for a CLI's completion installer command.

if ARGV[0]? == "__complete"
  ARGV.shift

  if ARGV[0]? == "completion"
    ARGV.shift

    Tabular.install_complete
  end
end
View source

docs.title: enum Tabular::Directive
docs.text: A bit map representing the different behaviors the shell can be instructed to have once completions have been provided.

docs.title: None = 0
docs.text: Indicates to let the shell perform its default behavior after completions have been provided.

docs.title: Error = 1
docs.text: Indicates an error occurred and completions should be ignored.

docs.title: NoSpace = 2
docs.text: Indicates that the shell should not add a space after the completion even if there is a single completion provided.

docs.title: NoFile = 4
docs.text: Indicates that the shell should not provide file completion even when no completion is provided.

docs.title: FilterExt = 8
docs.text: Indicates that the provided completions should be used as file extension filters.

docs.title: FilterDir = 16
docs.text: Indicates that only directory names should be provided in file completion.

docs.title: KeepOrder = 32
docs.text: Indicates that the shell should preserve the order in which the completions are provided

docs.title: #error?
docs.text:
Returns true if this enum value contains Error

View source

docs.title: #filter_dir?
docs.text:
Returns true if this enum value contains FilterDir

View source

docs.title: #filter_ext?
docs.text:
Returns true if this enum value contains FilterExt

View source

View source

docs.title: #no_file?

docs.title: #no_space?

docs.title: module Tabular::Error
docs.text: A collection of exceptions specific to Tabular.

docs.title: class Tabular::Error::Any inherits Exception
docs.text:
A base exception that all Tabular::Error exceptions can be caught with.

Direct known subclasses Tabular::Error::Argument Tabular::Error::Install Tabular::Error::Match Tabular::Error::Support

docs.title: class Tabular::Error::Argument inherits Tabular::Error::Any
docs.text: Raised when method arguments are incorrect or missing.

docs.title: class Tabular::Error::Install inherits Tabular::Error::Any
docs.text: Raised on issues with the installer.

docs.title: class Tabular::Error::Match inherits Tabular::Error::Any
docs.text: Raised when an argument that must Tabular::Token does not.

docs.title: class Tabular::Error::Support inherits Tabular::Error::Any
docs.text: Raised when a configuration is unsupported.

docs.title: enum Tabular::Kind
docs.text: Specifiers that determine the functionality of a Tabular::Token.

docs.title: Option = 1
docs.text: Specifies that a Tabular::Token represents an option parameter.

docs.title: Argument = 2
docs.text: Specifies that a Tabular::Token represents an argument parameter.

docs.title: Command = 3
docs.text: Specifies that a Tabular::Token represents an subcommand parameter.

docs.title: #argument?
docs.text:
Returns true if this enum value equals Argument

View source

docs.title: #command?
docs.text:
Returns true if this enum value equals Command

View source

docs.title: #directives
docs.text:
Returns the default Tabular::Directive of the Tabular::Kind.

  • Tabular::Kind::Argument — Tabular::Directive::None
  • All others — Tabular::Directive::NoFile
View source

docs.title: #option?
docs.text:
Returns true if this enum value equals Option

View source

docs.title: #runnable?
docs.text:
Returns true if the Tabular::Token represented by the Tabular::Kind should hand control back to the CLI when matched. Only Tabular::Kind::Command is runnable.

View source

docs.title: enum Tabular::Log
docs.text: A logger in which each member represents a logging level. Setting the $TABULAR_LOG_LEVEL environment variable from the shell to a file path directs all logging to that file.

docs.title: Fatal = 1
docs.text: A serious error, indicating that the program itself may be unable to continue running.

docs.title: Error = 2
docs.text: Due to a more serious problem, the software has not been able to perform some function.

docs.title: Warn = 3
docs.text: An indication that something unexpected happened, or that a problem might occur in the near future.

docs.title: Info = 4
docs.text: Confirmation that things are working as expected.

docs.title: Debug = 5
docs.text: Detailed information, typically only of interest to a developer trying to diagnose a problem.

docs.title: .level=(value : UInt32)
docs.text:
Set the global logging level.

View source

docs.title: .out(*msg)
docs.text:
Send output to STDOUT.

View source

docs.title: .silence
docs.text:
Silence all output, for testing.

View source

docs.text:
Returns true if this enum value equals Debug

Returns true if this enum value equals Error

View source

docs.title: #fatal?

Returns true if this enum value equals Fatal

docs.title: #info?

docs.title: struct Tabular::Token inherits Struct
docs.text: Represents a parameter whose name and aliases may be suggested and amtched during tab completion.

docs.title: NONE = Token.new(:none)
docs.text: Basically, Tabular::Token? minus the baggage.

docs.title: .new(kind : Kind, name : String = "", aliases = [] of String, description = "", *argument, directives : Directable | Nil = nil, delimiters = Tabular.delimiters)
docs.text:
Create a new Tabular::Token.

  • kind: See Tabular::Token#kind.
  • name: See Tabular::Token#name.
  • aliases: See Tabular::Token#aliases.
  • description: See Tabular::Token#description.
  • argument: See Tabular::Token#arguments.
  • directives: See Tabular::Token#directives.
  • delimiters: Ad hoc delimiters that will override Tabular.delimiters.
View source

docs.title: #aliases
docs.text:
A list of additional names the Tabular::Token will suggest/match.

View source

docs.title: #arguments
docs.text:
A set of Tabular::Kind::Argument types required by a Tabular::Kind::Option type.

View source

docs.title: #arguments?
docs.text:
Return true if a Tabular::Kind::Option requires any arguments.

View source

docs.title: #candidate(arg : String, & : String -> )
docs.text:
Yield suggestions for any names that contain arg.

View source

docs.title: #description
docs.text:
The description of the parameter the Tabular::Token represents.

View source

docs.title: #directives
docs.text:
Additional directives the Tabular::Token will send to the shell if suggested.

View source

docs.title: #kind
docs.text:
The representation of the Tabular::Token.

View source

docs.title: #match!(arg : String)
docs.text:
Returns self if arg is an exact match of any names. Otherwise, raise Tabular::Error::Match.

View source

docs.title: #match?(arg : String) : Bool
docs.text:
Return true if arg is an exact match of any names.

View source

docs.title: #name
docs.text:
The name of the parameter the Tabular::Token represents.

View source

docs.title: #next
docs.text:
For Tabular::Kind::Option token with #arguments?, yield the next Tabular::Kind::Argument token to the specified &block.

View source

docs.title: #to_s(io : IO)
docs.text:
Same as #inspect(io).

docs.title: Our Pledge
docs.text:
We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.

We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.

docs.title: Our Standards
docs.text:
Examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment for our community include:

  • Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people
  • Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences
  • Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
  • Accepting responsibility and apologizing to those affected by our mistakes, and learning from the experience
  • Focusing on what is best not just for us as individuals, but for the overall community

Examples of unacceptable behavior include:

  • The use of sexualized language or imagery, and sexual attention or advances of any kind
  • Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
  • Public or private harassment
  • Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or email address, without their explicit permission
  • Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting

docs.title: Enforcement Responsibilities
docs.text:
Community leaders are responsible for clarifying and enforcing our standards of acceptable behavior and will take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any behavior that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.

Community leaders have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, and will communicate reasons for moderation decisions when appropriate.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: This Code of Conduct applies within all community spaces, and also applies when an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces. Examples of representing our community include using an official e-mail address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline event.

docs.title: Enforcement
docs.text:
Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported to the community leaders responsible for enforcement at i.am@ajohn.dev. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated promptly and fairly.

All community leaders are obligated to respect the privacy and security of the reporter of any incident.

docs.title: Enforcement Guidelines
docs.text: Community leaders will follow these Community Impact Guidelines in determining the consequences for any action they deem in violation of this Code of Conduct:

docs.title: 1. Correction
docs.text:
Community Impact: Use of inappropriate language or other behavior deemed unprofessional or unwelcome in the community.

Consequence: A private, written warning from community leaders, providing clarity around the nature of the violation and an explanation of why the behavior was inappropriate. A public apology may be requested.

docs.title: 2. Warning
docs.text:
Community Impact: A violation through a single incident or series of actions.

Consequence: A warning with consequences for continued behavior. No interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, for a specified period of time. This includes avoiding interactions in community spaces as well as external channels like social media. Violating these terms may lead to a temporary or permanent ban.

docs.title: 3. Temporary Ban
docs.text:
Community Impact: A serious violation of community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior.

Consequence: A temporary ban from any sort of interaction or public communication with the community for a specified period of time. No public or private interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, is allowed during this period. Violating these terms may lead to a permanent ban.

docs.title: 4. Permanent Ban
docs.text:
Community Impact: Demonstrating a pattern of violation of community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment of an individual, or aggression toward or disparagement of classes of individuals.

Consequence: A permanent ban from any sort of public interaction within the community.

docs.title: Attribution
docs.text:
This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available at https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html.

Community Impact Guidelines were inspired by Mozilla's code of conduct enforcement ladder.

For answers to common questions about this code of conduct, see the FAQ at https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations are available at https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
1. Fork it (https://github.com/leshaunj/tabular/fork)
  2. Create your feature branch (git checkout -b my-new-feature)
  3. Commit your changes (git commit -am 'Add some feature')
  4. Push to the branch (git push origin my-new-feature)
  5. Create a new Pull Request
